awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Revealing the characteristics of high Reynolds number wakes with rotation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to reveal and characterize the behavior of the flow behind large rotating machines, such as wind or tidal turbines, as well as interactions between such machines. This will be achieved by the combination of a unique experimental flow facility and numerical modeling. Since these machines are typically very large, one needs to accurately account for effects due to inertia and rotation of the flow in model tests and simulations. By using a unique high-pressure flow facility, in combination with state of the art instrumentation, the details of the flow behind a wind turbine will be studied under conditions identical to those of a full scale modern wind or tidal turbine. This work will bridge the gap between previous laboratory research, numerical models, field experiments and the real-world applications, answering open fundamental questions about the scaling of the flow characteristics, as well as the power output and forces acting on the turbine. Furthermore, the numerical component of the project will allow us to perform unique comparisons and evaluation of available models and to improve these modeling approaches further. Improved models can in term result in more cost-efficient designs as well as a better understanding of maintenance guidelines.  

The primary objective of the proposed research program is to reveal and characterize the morphology and fundamental scaling of wakes generated by rotating machinery over an unprecedented range of Reynolds numbers. The research will enable a unique insight into the details of wakes created by wind and hydrokinetic turbines, which traditionally has not been possible in controlled environments. The combination of high Reynolds numbers and rotation makes attempts to accurately simulate these flows very challenging. The proposed research will combine a recently developed experimental test facility, a custom designed Particle Image Velocimetry system, and novel nanoscale sensors to enable detailed and accurate characterization of the fluid mechanics within rotating wakes. Focus will be aimed at providing knowledge that can improve our ability to model and predict the performance and interactions between these kinds of machines. The proposed research program will permit us to bridge the current gap between previous laboratory research, numerical models, field experiments and the real-world applications, answering open fundamental questions about the scaling and dynamics of the momentum distribution, turbulent fluctuations, structure and meandering of the wake as well as scalability of conventional research efforts.
The main objective of the education part of the proposed project is to integrate design into an introductory engineering laboratory course, in order to give the students ownership of the labs and teach them modern engineering tools in an interdisciplinary fashion. The new course will challenge the students to build their own tools and test benches from robust, low cost and open source components to test their ideas and the concepts they have read about.  The format of the proposed laboratory course is such that it can be easily adopted by other educators and will be cost efficient.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, wakes of wind turbines and approaches to model them, were investigated in a laboratory setting at conditions that mimic those of the real world. These conditions were achieved using a highly pressurized flow facility that allows the physics of the flow both around and behind the turbines to be reproduced even if the physical size of the setup is two orders of magnitude smaller than in the field. A large dataset of the forces, aerodynamic power, and axial velocity measurements in the wake of the rotor, acquired at different downstream locations and at different operating conditions, were collected using state of the art sensing techniques. Nanoscale hot wire anemometry was used to guarantee fully resolved measurements, something that can be challenging when testing at small length scales. Effects of the large length scale of modern wind turbines on the statistics (through the Reynolds number) and the morphology of the wake, including dominant flow features within it, were investigated. It was shown through spectral analysis that the tip vortices, which are created when the blades rotate, influence the flow over a wide range of turbulent length scales. This, in term affects the evolution of the entire wake, which is recovering faster due to the higher turbulence levels generated by the tip vortices.  It was also shown that a decrease in the tip speed ratio (indicator of rational effects) leads to an increase in the energy content of the broadband tip vortex scales, which in turn directly contribute to accelerated wake recovery. This conclusion indicates that a turbine with a more energetic tip vortex can enable more rapid wake recovery, an important variable when considering turbine placement in wind farms. Another flow feature that was studied thoroughly was that of wake meandering, which has been observed in previous studies, but lacks a clear explanation. Although prior research indicated that wake meandering requires multiple diameters downstream of the turbine to develop, the unique measurements of this project clearly show that the meandering starts much earlier and was observed even less than one diameter downstream of the turbine. Further, wake meandering was found to be present at all downstream locations surveyed, indicating that it will have a strong effect on the wake’s evolution, both close to and far from the turbine. In addition to wake meandering and tip vortices, the wake of a wind turbine is also expected to exhibit evidence of vortices created at the root of the blades. Previous investigations of this region, especially at high Reynolds numbers, is scarce and conclusions often not in agreement. Here, it was clearly shown that there is shedding in this region, but that the shedding is independent of rational rate of the turbine, leading to the hypothesis that it acts more like a shedding shear-layer, similar to that behind a bluff body. Through the introduction of a new geometric length scale, based on the rotor solidity, it could be shown that it is most likely a solidity-driven flow feature.

In addition to the flow around and behind rotating turbines, the flows around and behind porous disks have been studied both theoretically and experimentally. Such disks (often referred to as actuator disks) often serve as models for wind turbines when wind farms or turbine interactions are investigated. Through theoretical work that extends earlier models, the forces on and velocities in the wake of a porous disk could be modeled, even at high solidity, without any empirical input. Further, new design criteria were introduced when using porous disks to model the wakes of rotating turbines. Previous designs often require a priori knowledge about the flow behind the rotor, which defeats the whole purpose of modeling it. The new design criteria resolve this issue, and a novel design was shown to replicate the wake well.  It is expected that the work supported through this project will yield new and exciting research directions, and that the dataset will serve as an important reference case for modelers.
